reviewText: PAUL VI (2010, approx. 3 hours, Italian w/subtitles) is a class-act Italian production showing, more or less, the life of Giovanni Battista Montini, Pope Paul VI. Filmed all over Italy from what I can see, this quiet, meditative biography shows Pope Paul as a man set against all manner of tyranny, somewhat like Gandhi. While I question that rose-tinted-spectacles outlook a little, there is nothing wrong with this as a biographical drama.The wife says this bores her out of her mind. Though I have seen it three times, I can see why she's bored: it is a dry piece of toast, but it is quality toast ready for some caviar. The performances are nuanced, delicate and Shakespearean in caliber. The locations are stunning and the art direction, while it has the made-for-television stigma, is also flawless.I'm a big fan of such films, and they make me cry out in woe that we have no comparable films about rabbis or Buddhist priests. But we have these types of productions, and I for one would love to see many more of them. There is the splendidPope John Paul II(vid. my review) andJohn XXIIIwhich I haven't seen -  but there are several dozen popes to go!

reviewText: This is a well presented life story of the Papacy of Cardinal Montini, who succeeded the highly likeable and popular Pope John XXII.  He faced a time of turmoil and unrest and a time when Communism seemed to be gaining the upper hand in Europe.  He first started to travel around the world making him accessible to the millions of faithful.  He wrote several beautiful  encyclicals but unfortunately will always be remembered for the fateful one wherein he reiterated that contraception is not for practicing Catholics and gave reasons for his decision despite the fact that his Counselors were against this decision.A very thought provoking movie.

reviewText: I have been watching many of the Italian-made religious/spiritual dramas.  This film about the life and his pontiifcate of Paul VI (Paul VI (Giovanni Battista Enrico Antonio Maria Montini) was quite moving in that it showed him to be a man of ideals, love, amicability, political stands, hope and global outreach. This is achieved by the brilliant performance by Fabrizio Gifuni. The film starts with him in his late-20s when he was appointed to serve in the Vatican's Secretariat of State in 1922.  The film opens in 1978 and then switches to his 32 years in the office and then back to his 16-year reign as pope (6/21/63 to 8/6/78). Although there are a couple more flashbacks, the film flows evenly and is a beautiful and emotionally-moving experience.  One of the themes that is prevalent throughout the film is Pope Paul VI's concept of "a civilization of love." The film also focuses on the pope's inheriting Pope John XXIII's ecumenical congress - the Second Vatican Council and Paul VI's mission to improve ecumenical relations with (Eastern) Orthodox and Protestant churches. The latter part of the film also spotlights his many which historic meetings, agreements and trips to Israel, India, Africa and South America.  Scattered throughout the movie are facts such as he was the first pope to travel by plane, the first to take a stand on Viet Nam and his staunch defiance of facism and terrorism.Personally, Pope Paul VI came across as a man with a hope for humanity, a staunch opponent of terrorism, a lover of all people, a friend of the laborer and a man with a heart for the poor and hopeless.  The movie spends a lot of time on his personal struggles with his interpretation of the work of Vatican Council.  The film accurately covers the pope's diplomatic approach with the conflicting various groups within the Catholic Church laity and priests. Some of the major church issues that are depicted are the pope's attempt to deal with the falling church attendance, the loss of many priests, the question of birth contraception, social injustice and unjust government. We can appreciate the magnitude and depth of his reforms by seeing the emotions on his face as portrayed by Fabrizio Gifuni.I only had a few reservations about the film.  One, it did not focus (except for one rosary reference) to Paul VI's strong Marian devotion and his numerous visits to Marian shrines and and three Marian encyclicals. Second, there is no mention of his death 8/6/78, the Feast of the Transfiguration, his beatification in 1993, and his subsequent title "Servant of God".
summary: Pope Paul VI - Venerable ambassador of love and peace

reviewText: A three-hour Italian (with English subtitles) TV miniseries, "Paul VI: The Pope in the Tempest" displays all the virtues and vices of the many Italian religious epics produced by RAI and Lux Vide. As a fan of these Italian religious epics, I know there a lot of dogs ("Paul the Apostle") as well as great flicks (TNT Bible Series) on DVD from these companies. The better ones tend to be international co-productions with American actors and artistic collaboration from other countries, like the deeply moving 2005 CBS miniseries "Pope John Paul II" with Jon Voight and Cary Elwes. But some of the Italian-language epics (like the recent "St. Barbara") are excellent too. (Ignatius Press has the distribution rights to release many of these films on DVD in the U.S. market.) This one, "Paul VI," falls somewhere in the middle of the heap.While it is slickly produced and free of the poor English dubbing (it is in Italian with English subtitles) that the Italians impose in some other international co-productions like Pius XII, this film also makes some poor decisions in how it presents Pope Paul VI and in what it chooses to highlight from his life. On the positive side, it depicts a broad swath of church figures and historical periods, including four popes (Pius XI, Pius XII, John XXIII, Paul VI, the future John Paul II) and a host of Vatican authorities rarely shown on film. One such figure is Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the French ecclesiastic who rejected the new mass and its vernacular language option after Vatican II, and this movie gets kudos for daring to show a meeting between Lefebvre and Paul VI, with the archbishop walking out angrily after Paul tries to buy his favor with a beautiful chalice. That's an unusually tense scene in a film otherwise free of dramatic conflict and deep human interactions. It generally depicts Paul in a positive light with an emphasis on his long Vatican career and firm leadership in the tumultuous 20th century, sometimes showing things (the protagonist's role in Pius XI making a concordat with Mussolini and the suffering of Pius XII during WWII) that are rarely filmed.It starts with young Giovanni Montini (the future Paul) already as a priest, but it covers all the major bases it needs to cover in a life of Paul VI. Unfortunately, the film is also episodic, dull, and overly hagiographic in its treatment of Paul's life. Like the Jon Voight-headlined film "Pope John Paul II," it starts with a framing device and flashback, but this one -- the abduction of President Moro in 1978 -- is rather dull and only tangentially relates to our protagonist's life. Surely there was a more representative moment from Montini's life to highlight. Rather than giving us a full human portrait of Paul VI, the film brushes past the controversies of his papacy with barely any acknowledgment, giving us a one-dimensional saintly father figure who doesn't do anything particularly interesting on screen and who never faces any real difficulties.  It also presents Paul as a curial bureaucrat who spent most of his life within the rarified walls of Vatican City, removed from real contact with ordinary people. This approach makes for interesting but tremendously dull filmmaking. Rather than emphasizing the deeper struggles of Paul's backstory or papacy, like the general reactions to "Humane Vitae" (which features a bit in the second half) and Vatican II, this film brushes over them with canned speechifying in favor of an emphasis on Paul's role as an opponent of Italian fascism and proponent of democratic freedoms.These latter themes were handled far better in the superior "Pope John Paul II," where Voight and Cary Elwes showed us a very human and fallible pope with a far more interesting backstory. While depicting Paul's Italian political alliances may be fascinating to Italian television audiences who revel in the details of 20th century Italian politics, it unfortunately reduces the story of a world historical figure to incredibly small proportions, neglecting topics of wider interest to viewers. In the film's second half, we finally escape some of these political issues for a look at the significant historical moments of Paul's papacy, but nothing here is terribly involving. Instead of dramatizing the big moments of Paul's papacy, we get a lot of documentary footage and people talking about historical events, rather than the film actually attempting to show them. There is even a hokey and particularly pointless appearance by Karol Wojtyla, the future John Paul II, with silly foreshadowing about his destiny. This makes for a remarkably talky and dull viewing experience. Fabrizio Gifuni is a likable Paul, but is so relentlessly saintly that it's impossible to identify with him as a real human being, and his continual speechmaking before assembled crowds of faux-reverent extras (one of the major artistic vices of this genre) becomes grating after awhile, and his acting lacks in the emotional resonance that would elevate this production above its TV origins. It's a well-produced and interesting film, but there are undoubtedly many better ways to tell this man's story without whitewashing it.
summary: Well done but meandering Italian biopic of Pope Paul VI
